BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. In the course of the day danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are being formed by the southerly wind will become increasingly prone to triggering. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes large and, in many cases, very large natural avalanches are possible. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Saturday above approximately 1800 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular at intermediate and high altitudes and along the border with Switzerland.
These weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
The snowpack will become unstable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong over a wide area in particular along the border with Switzerland. The fresh snow and also in particular the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming over a wide area represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. In the course of the day danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are being formed by the southerly wind will become increasingly prone to triggering. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In particular at intermediate and high altitudes large and, in many cases, very large natural avalanches are possible. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Saturday above approximately 1800 m. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies in particular at intermediate and high altitudes and along the border with Switzerland.
These weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
The snowpack will become unstable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be strong over a wide area in particular along the border with Switzerland. The fresh snow and also in particular the sometimes large wind slabs that are forming over a wide area represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

As a consequence of the heavy snowfall individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 1800 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects in all altitude zones. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Sunday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Some mostly small natural avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. On steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes dry slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow to below approximately 1400 m: Gradual increase in danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size, in the regions exposed to a lot of new snow especially above approximately 2000 m and.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be large in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
25 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Saturday above approximately 2000 m. The new snow will be deposited on bare ground over a wide area, in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at intermediate and high altitudes, along the border with France.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is soft and has a loosely bonded surface. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area a lot of new snow to below approximately 1600 m. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More snow than expected will fall in particular along the border with France. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more frequent avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be very large in some cases.
New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially above approximately 2200 m and. The danger exists primarily in alpine snow sports terrain. Avalanches capable of reaching valley bottoms and endangering exposed transportation routes are unlikely to occur.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Saturday above approximately 2200 m. The new snow will be deposited on bare ground over a wide area, in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, along the border with France.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is soft and has a loosely bonded surface. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area new snow. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
More snow than expected will fall in particular along the border with France. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation more frequent avalanches are possible as the day progresses, but they can be very large in some cases.
New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. In the regions exposed to a lot of new snow this applies especially above approximately 2200 m and. The danger exists primarily in alpine snow sports terrain. Avalanches capable of reaching valley bottoms and endangering exposed transportation routes are unlikely to occur.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until Saturday above approximately 2200 m. The new snow will be deposited on bare ground over a wide area, in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. This applies especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, along the border with France.
Towards its surface, the snowpack is soft and has a loosely bonded surface. The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area new snow. The avalanche danger will increase.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind from southerly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form in particular at elevated altitudes. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes above the tree line, especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1300 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in particular on shady slopes above the tree line.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall on Sunday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

As a consequence of the heavy snowfall individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 25 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects in all altitude zones. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and strong wind.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation there will be a gradual increase in the avalanche danger to level 3 (considerable). The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects above approximately 1800 m.
In particular on steep slopes natural avalanches are possible.
Large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible in particular in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of snowfall and the strong southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
The rain will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack on steep north facing slopes below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall in some regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the new snow. Natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 2000 m. In regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The sometimes moderate wind will transport the new snow.
On steep slopes and at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain natural dry avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching the valleys, must be expected in isolated cases.
Single winter sport participants can release avalanches in some places. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Little snow fell on Friday. Friday: 5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m. In many places new snow is being deposited on bare ground (--), in particular on sunny slopes and at low and intermediate altitudes.
Below approximately 2200 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In all aspects there will be a gradual decrease in the danger of dry avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind. Natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 2000 m. In regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The sometimes moderate wind will transport the new snow.
On steep slopes and at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain natural dry avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. From starting zones at higher altitudes natural avalanches, capable of reaching the valleys, must be expected in isolated cases.
The barely recognisable wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen since Thursday in particular along the border with France. Friday: 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on a weakly bonded old snowpack on rather lightly snow-covered shady slopes. Will be deposited on a crust on steep south, west and southeast facing slopes.
Below approximately 2200 m only a little snow is lying on south and southwest facing slopes. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the moderate to strong northwesterly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. On steep slopes and on wind-loaded slopes dry slab avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even quite large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation.
New snow above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the precipitation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually at intermediate and high altitudes.
Small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized avalanches are possible in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
Natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The rain will give rise to increasing and thorough wetting of the snowpack below approximately 2000 m.
As a consequence of snowfall and the strong southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack. In particular on south facing slopes a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: A lot of snow will fall in some regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

As a consequence of the heavy snowfall individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 1800 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects in all altitude zones.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. They can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases. Avalanches can reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. At elevated altitudes and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation such avalanche prone locations are more widespread.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Friday. Over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall on Saturday above approximately 1400 m. The sometimes strong wind will transport the new snow. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers on shady slopes above the tree line. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall until Sunday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. A latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above the tree line sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep shady slopes, especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Avalanches can in isolated cases reach medium size. At elevated altitudes and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation such avalanche prone locations are more widespread.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, in particular medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 1400 m. The strong wind will transport the new snow. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers on shady slopes.
The old snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some regions 5 to 15 cm of snow will fall until Sunday. The wind will be strong in some cases. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence on steep north, northeast and northwest facing slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: On shady slopes and on wind-loaded slopes the likelihood of dry avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes storm force wind from southwesterly directions, avalanche prone wind slabs will form. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant. Mostly the avalanches are medium-sized. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes above approximately 2000 m, and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

As a consequence of the heavy snowfall individual natural loose snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes in all aspects especially above the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Saturday above approximately 1800 m. The sometimes storm force wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects in all altitude zones. Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Sunday. Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow at high altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and wind individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1700 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. In high Alpine regions a little snow is lying. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. These are to be found especially at high altitude. Some fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs will be deposited on a quite favourable old snowpack above approximately 1800 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The danger of wet and gliding avalanches in all regions is within the uppermost range of danger level.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area in some localities up to 50 cm of snow will fall above approximately 1800 m. The new snow can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line.
